metadata.title: An Initial Functional and Security Coverage Analysis of AWS Security Agent Against the OWASP Top 10 (2025)
metadata.author: Ivan Bylina

abstract: This study presents an initial functional and security coverage analysis of AWS Security Agent, a newly introduced AWS-managed, GenAI-enabled security assessment service designed to support design review, code analysis, and penetration testing within the software development lifecycle. The evaluation is based on empirical testing of the service, supplemented by a systematic review of publicly available AWS documentation. The study examines three core capabilities: design security review, code security review and on-demand penetration testing, evaluates their implementation characteristics, operational limitations, and coverage of the OWASP Top 10 (2025) application security risks. Results indicate support for context-aware, multi-step penetration testing and real-time pull-request analysis, with effective detection of injection vulnerabilities. OWASP Top 10 coverage analysis reveals significant variation across risk categories, with strongest coverage in injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage in security misconfiguration and insecure design, and weakest coverage in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, and security logging. This work provides an objective, practitioner-focused assessment of current capabilities and limitations and does not constitute a security certification or endorsement of the service.

sections.title: Introduction
paragraphs: Application security teams must secure applications as they evolve through design, coding and deployment. Traditional security reviews and penetration tests are typically manual and scheduled infrequently, leading to gaps and late findings. AWS introduced the "Security Agent" as a AI agent designed to embed security into each stage of the software development lifecycle [1]. The service was first publicly announced at AWS re:Invent 2025, held December 1-5, 2025, signaling AWSâs intent to operationalize generative AI-assisted security reviews within mainstream development workflows [2]. The agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface, aiming to make expert-level security assessments available on demand and at scale [1]. The official documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent operates across AWS, on-premise, hybrid, multicloud, and SaaS environments [1] and consolidates findings from design, code and penetration tests in one place.

subsections.title: Design Security Review
paragraphs: The design review capability allows security teams to upload design documents (architectural diagrams, system designs, data-flow diagrams and threat models) and assess them against organizational security requirements. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent shifts security left by providing real-time security feedback on design documents and assessing compliance with organizational security requirements before any code is written [1]. Security teams upload documents through the web application and receive remediation guidance to prioritize findings [1]. The agent supports custom security requirements-teams can define description, applicability, compliance criteria and remediation guidance for each requirement. During testing, it was noted that custom requirements are defined through free-text fields limited to 500 characters for descriptions and 10 000 characters for other fields, and the underlying model interprets them, which may change over time. The design review runs entirely in the external web application opened from the AWS console. Supported formats include markdown, PDF and common architectural diagram formats, but uploading is done manually; there is currently no CLI or API to automate submissions.

subsections.title: Code Security Review
paragraphs: Code review analyzes pull requests in source control repositories against security requirements and the OWASP Top 10. The official AWS documentation states that AWS Security Agent proactively secures applications by analyzing pull requests against organizational security requirements and common vulnerabilities like missing input validation and SQL injection risks [1]. Developers receive remediation guidance directly in their GitHub workflow [1]. The official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub confirms that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and that draft pull requests are not analyzed [3]. The AWS News Feed article notes that the agent's code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The official AWS documentation only mentions GitHub integration [3]. During testing, it was observed that the public preview integrates only with GitHub via a GitHub App, supports up to 20 private repositories per integration [5] and does not scan public repositories. Pull requests are the only unit of analysis - full repository scans are not supported. Remediation guidance and suggested fixes are posted directly in the developer's workflow, but customizing the checks beyond the defined security requirements is limited.

subsections.title: On-Demand Penetration Testing
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent's penetration testing capability performs multi-step attack simulations on web applications. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent delivers on-demand penetration testing by deploying specialized AI agents to discover, validate, report and remediate security vulnerabilities through tailored multi-step attack scenarios [1]. The agent understands the application's context by analyzing source code and documentation to identify and exploit vulnerabilities that automated security scanning tools cannot find [1]. It documents findings with impact analysis, reproducible attack paths, and creates pull requests with ready-to-implement code fixes [1]. The official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests specifies that only verified domains can be included in penetration tests and that VPC configuration is only required for testing private applications hosted within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud [6]. It is promoted as automating context-aware penetration tests that scale across many applications [4]. The National CIO Review notes that the agent continuously scans workloads for vulnerabilities and performs penetration testing tailored to the application's structure and intended behavior, eliminating the need to wait for humanâled assessments [7]. The ComputerWeekly report adds that the agent understands the design, code and security requirements of a workload and can create a customised attack plan to expose vulnerabilities before an application reaches production [8]. During testing, it was noted that all penetration tests require a verified domain (with DNS TXT record) [6], and for private applications hosted within a VPC, additional VPC configuration is also required [6]. Tests can include contextual artifacts such as API documentation, threat models, source code archives and GitHub repositories. Only HTTP/HTTPS targets are supported; custom ports and other protocols are not. The agent creates multiple action groups (information disclosure, business logic vulnerabilities, unrestricted resource consumption, authentication bypass, etc.), uses static analysis tasks to inspect the source, and then launches validators that exploit vulnerabilities to minimise false positives. The risk categories available for testing include arbitrary file upload, code injection, command injection, crossâsite scripting (XSS), insecure direct object references, JSON Web Token vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, serverâside request forgery (SSRF), serverâside template injection, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks.

subsections.title: Setup and Permissions
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent was tested using a read-only IAM user with permissions gradually added. The web console provided clear error messages for many missing permissions, but some errors required examining logs to identify the missing IAM policies. The agent can only be enabled via the AWS console; there is no CLI, CloudFormation template or SDK interface for configuration-making it a click-ops process. All interactions occur via a web console with no CLI or official AWS CLI commands available. The preview is available only in the us-east-1 region and requires creation of an "Agent Space". Connecting GitHub triggers installation of a GitHub App with repository access restricted to selected or all repositories.

subsections.title: Design Review Findings
paragraphs: The design review accepts supported file types via manual upload. In some highly regulated environments, uploading documents through a web UI may be blocked, limiting adoption. The service was tested with basic design documents, and it was observed that policies such as "Secure by Default, Tenant Isolation, Secret Protection, Trusted Cryptography, Audit Logging, Authorization, Log Protection, Information Protection, Privileged Access and Authentication" were applied. When the design intentionally violated requirements, the agent failed corresponding policies; when the design mentioned the required topics, half of the policies were marked as needing more details. Uploading irrelevant documents led to all policies being marked not applicable. Custom security requirements worked as expected; a test rule designed to block specific fictional terms was triggered when related keywords appeared in variable names. However, the manual upload process and lack of automation make it difficult to integrate design review into CI/CD pipelines. During testing, it was noted that the underlying language model performing analysis is not documented; thus the behaviour may change as models are updated. This lack of determinism makes it difficult to rely on the tool for strict policy enforcement.

subsections.title: Code Review Findings
paragraphs: Code review worked only for private GitHub repositories configured through the GitHub App. Pull requests were evaluated against the same security requirements used for design review and against common vulnerability patterns. The agent does not analyze entire codebases-only changes in pull requests. Custom security requirements could be reused across design and code reviews. There is no support for public repositories, and integration with other source control systems (Bitbucket, GitLab, CodeCommit) was not present in the preview. The tool offers two modes: one to check custom security requirements and another to detect "security vulnerability findings" that resemble the output of Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer; the latter uses rules similar to open-source tools like Bandit and Infer.

subsections.title: Penetration Testing Findings
paragraphs: To start a penetration test, users must verify ownership of a target domain by creating a DNS TXT record. Automatic verification via Route53 often fails, requiring manual DNS record creation. The penetration testing workflow opens in an external web application separate from the main AWS console. Tests can target an external domain or run from within a VPC; however, the tool does not support VPCs using the 10.0.0.0/16 CIDR because it conflicts with the agent's addressing. Custom ports and non-HTTP protocols are unsupported; specifying a port in the URL causes the run to start but never succeeds. When a VPC is selected, outbound internet connectivity is required even to fetch GitHub context. Penetration tests also request CloudWatch log groups as destinations, but pre-created log groups sometimes fail validation due to undocumented naming conventions; leaving the field blank allows the agent to create log groups automatically. Contextual resources can include S3 buckets (only plaintext API documentation, threat models or zipped source code archives), GitHub repositories and plainâtext credentials via the UI. Lambda functions and Secrets Manager entries are used solely to provide authentication credentials. During scanning, the agent builds a sitemap, performs static analysis of frameworks, business logic, important flows and misconfigurations, and then launches validator tasks for risk categories such as arbitrary file upload, code and command injection, XSS, IDOR, JWT vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, SSRF, SSTI, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks. The agent uses tools like testssl.sh to check TLS configurations. It produces detailed findings with CVSS scores, exploit steps and remediation guidance. However, exploitation of complex vulnerabilities that require running external tooling or interacting with local services (labelled "Hard" during testing) is not supported. Custom exploitation code added to the context caused hallucinations - e.g., the agent incorrectly marked a vulnerability as CVE-2021-21311 based on proof for CVE-2018-7667. Additionally, the service prohibits creation of custom infrastructure or use of localhost services, limiting validation of sophisticated scenarios.

sections.title: Limitations and Gaps
paragraphs: The following tables summarise limitations identified during testing and map them to available documentation where possible. Table 1 lists limitations mentioned in official AWS sources (blogs and documentation) and confirmed through testing. Table 2 lists limitations observed during testing that are not mentioned in the sources reviewed.

tables.caption: Table 1 - Documented limitations
rows: Service is in preview and available only in US East (N. Virginia). AWS News Feed notes that AWS Security Agent is free during the preview and available only in the US East (N. Virginia) region [4].

Access is through a web-based interface with no CLI, API, or scheduling capabilities. Official AWS documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface [1]. Official AWS documentation on security considerations explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule the pen test runs" [9]. Configuration, design uploads, repository integration and test execution can only be performed via the console and external web app; there is no AWS CLI or SDK support. Tests must be triggered manually via the console; cannot integrate penetration tests into CI/CD pipelines or scheduled assessments.

Code review analyzes GitHub pull requests rather than full repositories. AWS News Feed states that code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The preview only reviews pull requests on private repositories; it does not scan entire codebases.

Only GitHub integration available for code review. Official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub states that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and only GitHub is mentioned throughout the documentation [3]. The documentation does not mention support for other source control systems. The preview only supports GitHub integration; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available.

Limit of 20 integrated resources per integration. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrated resources per integration are limited to 20 per integration, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Large organizations may have more repositories than allowed and must manage multiple integrations or agent spaces.

Limit of 20 integrations per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrations are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with many repositories may need to create multiple agent spaces or request quota increases.

Limit of 20 custom security requirements per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that custom security requirements are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with extensive security policies may need to prioritize which requirements to configure.

Concurrent pentest runs limited to 5 per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that concurrent pentest runs are limited to 5 per account per region, though this quota is adjustable [5]. Multiple penetration tests can run simultaneously, but the limit may require scheduling for organizations with high testing needs.

Public repositories unsupported. Official AWS documentation on security best practices explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories. It will not comment on public repositories or open-source projects where security findings would be publicly visible" [10]. Only private repositories can be scanned, preventing open-source projects from using the service.

VPC CIDR range 10.0.0.0/16 not supported. Official AWS documentation on connecting agent to private VPC resources explicitly states that "For VPC penetration tests, VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported" [11]. Common corporate VPC ranges conflict with the agent; penetration tests using VPCs with this CIDR range will fail.

VPC must have outbound internet connectivity. Official AWS documentation on infrastructure security states that "AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations" [12]. Penetration tests inside a VPC fail if there is no outbound connectivity.

tables.caption: Table 2 - Limitations observed in the preview not documented in sources
rows: Design review and code review require manual file uploads and cannot fetch from VPC or internal file shares.
Only HTTP/HTTPS targets supported; custom ports and non-HTTP protocols are not supported.
Risk of hallucinated vulnerabilities when additional exploit code is provided, potentially misattributing vulnerabilities.

Complex exploitation scenarios requiring custom tooling or local services are unsupported. The agent runs from a Docker container with Kali Linux that has limited built-in tooling available, and internal guardrails reduce fluency, preventing support for advanced attack scenarios.
Underlying language model and its updates are not exposed, affecting result reproducibility and determinism.

Agent does not have access to the runtime environment of the host under test (filesystem, OS, or application runtime), limiting analysis of file system-level permissions, ownership, temporary files, operating system-specific features, and runtime memory inspection to detect cleartext storage in memory or analyze memory-based vulnerabilities.

Missing specific vulnerability testing capabilities - certain vulnerability types are not explicitly tested (e.g., CSRF, CRLF injection, log injection, cookie integrity checking, MFA, file upload testing, HTTP request/response smuggling, browser cache security testing, window.opener vulnerability testing, log file content analysis).

Limited static code analysis scope - code scanner focuses on important flows and framework analysis rather than comprehensive static analysis (e.g., variable/field modifiers, exception handling patterns, debugging code, comment scanning, mass assignment patterns, generic exception declarations). Additionally, code scanner does not perform comprehensive analysis of cryptographic implementation details via static code analysis (e.g., IV generation, nonce reuse, key pair reuse, RSA padding selection) or runtime random number generator testing (entropy, seed validation, PRNG algorithm analysis).

No dependency vulnerability analysis - tool scans dependency manifest files (package.json, requirements.txt, pom.xml, go.mod, composer.json) for framework identification but does not check component versions against vulnerability databases (CVE scanning, SBOM generation, transitive dependency analysis, maintenance status checking).

paragraphsAfter: Table 2 summarises limitations observed in the preview that are not mentioned in the documentation reviewed.

subsections.title: Coverage Visualization
paragraphs: Figure 1 presents an area chart visualizing the OWASP Top 10 coverage percentages across all risk categories, illustrating the significant variation in coverage from complete coverage in injection vulnerabilities to no coverage in software supply chain failures.

chart.caption: Figure 1 - OWASP Top 10 (2025) Coverage by AWS Security Agent
labels: A08: Software or Data Integrity Failures
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures

table.caption: Table 3a - A01: Broken Access Control Coverage by AWS Security Agent*
table.note: * The evaluation was conducted against a sample simplified applications with known vulnerabilities. As a result, additional weaknesses or architectural limitations commonly observed in real-world, large-scale applications may not be represented. Analysis of such scenarios is outside the scope of this research.
rows: CWE-1275: Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute
Partial

Description: The service scans endpoints for TLS/SSL vulnerabilities but does not explicitly validate SameSite cookie attributes. Evidence: Network scanner action groups test TLS/SSL protocol security but do not include cookie attribute validation. Limitations: Cookie security attributes are not part of the network scanning scope [UL-007].
CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
Covered

Description: The service detects exposure of sensitive information through information disclosure testing and IDOR findings. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of user enumeration and information disclosure vulnerabilities.
CWE-201: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data
Partial

Description: The service may detect sensitive information through information disclosure testing but does not explicitly test for insertion into sent data vectors. Evidence: Information disclosure action groups and static analysis may detect sensitive information indirectly. Limitations: Explicit testing for insertion of sensitive information into sent data (headers, POST data, query parameters) is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-219: Storage of File with Sensitive Data Under Web Root
Partial

Description: The service tests for file access through path traversal but does not explicitly validate file storage locations relative to web root. Evidence: Path traversal and information disclosure action groups test for accessible files. Limitations: Explicit validation of file storage locations relative to web root directory is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-22: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
Covered

Description: The service includes dedicated path traversal testing action groups that systematically test for directory traversal vulnerabilities. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate comprehensive path traversal vulnerability assessment including framework-specific bypass techniques.
CWE-23: Relative Path Traversal
Covered

Description: Relative path traversal is tested as part of comprehensive path traversal testing capabilities. Evidence: Path traversal action groups test for both relative and absolute path traversal vulnerabilities.
CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions
Partial

Description: The service tests for privilege escalation and access control violations but does not explicitly validate default permission settings. Evidence: Privilege escalation action groups test for access control issues. Limitations: Explicit validation of default permission settings for resources, files, or database objects is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-281: Improper Preservation of Permissions
Not Covered

Description: This vulnerability requires file system-level analysis of permission preservation across file operations. Evidence: The tool focuses on web application penetration testing through HTTP/HTTPS interfaces rather than file system-level permission analysis. Limitations: File system operations are not part of the testing scope as the tool operates at the application layer [UL-006].
CWE-282: Improper Ownership Management
Not Covered

Description: This vulnerability requires file system-level analysis of ownership management across file operations. Evidence: The tool focuses on web application penetration testing rather than file system-level ownership analysis. Limitations: File system operations are not part of the testing scope as the tool operates at the application layer [UL-006].
CWE-283: Unverified Ownership
Partial

Description: The service detects IDOR vulnerabilities which may indicate missing ownership verification but does not explicitly test ownership verification mechanisms. Evidence: IDOR action groups test for authorization bypass through user-controlled keys. Limitations: Explicit validation of ownership verification mechanisms is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-284: Improper Access Control
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects improper access control violations where functionality should be restricted to specific roles but is available to any authenticated user. Evidence: Penetration test findings explicitly identify improper access control including privilege escalation testing demonstrating vertical and horizontal escalation.
CWE-285: Improper Authorization
Covered

Description: The service detects improper authorization through findings that demonstrate authorization bypass and privilege escalation. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate authorization bypass including SQL injection-based authentication bypass and session manipulation testing.
CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include CSRF testing in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of CSRF testing, CSRF token validation, or CSRF attack simulation. Limitations: CSRF testing is completely absent from the tool's capabilities [UL-007].
CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
Covered

Description: The service detects exposure of private personal information through IDOR and information disclosure findings. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of user enumeration and cross-user data access vulnerabilities.
CWE-36: Absolute Path Traversal
Covered

Description: Absolute path traversal is tested as part of comprehensive path traversal testing capabilities. Evidence: Path traversal action groups test for both relative and absolute path traversal vulnerabilities.
CWE-377: Insecure Temporary File
Not Covered

Description: This vulnerability requires file system-level analysis of temporary file creation and permissions. Evidence: The tool focuses on web application penetration testing through HTTP/HTTPS interfaces rather than file system-level temporary file analysis. Limitations: File system operations are not part of the testing scope as the tool operates at the application layer [UL-006].
CWE-379: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions
Not Covered

Description: This vulnerability requires file system-level analysis of temporary file directory permissions. Evidence: The tool focuses on web application penetration testing rather than file system-level temporary file directory analysis. Limitations: File system operations are not part of the testing scope as the tool operates at the application layer [UL-006].
CWE-402: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')
Partial

Description: The service may detect resource leaks indirectly through information disclosure and SSRF testing but does not explicitly test for transmission of private resources into unauthorized contexts. Evidence: Information disclosure and SSRF action groups test for resource access. Limitations: Explicit testing for transmission of private resources into unauthorized contexts is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-424: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
Covered

Description: The service tests for improper protection of alternate paths through privilege escalation and IDOR testing. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate comprehensive testing of alternate access paths including session manipulation, cookie tampering, and HTTP verb tampering.
CWE-425: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
Covered

Description: The service tests for forced browsing through authenticated runtime testing and privilege escalation action groups. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate comprehensive forced browsing testing including accessing privileged pages as standard users and systematic endpoint discovery.
CWE-441: Unintended Proxy or Intermediary ('Confused Deputy')
Partial

Description: The service may detect confused deputy issues through SSRF testing but does not explicitly test for proxy/intermediary functionality. Evidence: SSRF action groups test for server-side request forgery vulnerabilities. Limitations: Explicit validation of proxy/intermediary functionality is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-497: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
Covered

Description: The service detects exposure of sensitive system information through information disclosure testing. Evidence: Information disclosure action groups and findings demonstrate detection of system information exposure.
CWE-538: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory
Partial

Description: The service tests for file access through path traversal and information disclosure but does not explicitly test for insertion of sensitive information into externally-accessible locations. Evidence: Information disclosure and path traversal action groups test for accessible files. Limitations: Explicit testing for insertion of sensitive information into externally-accessible files is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
Covered

Description: The service includes static analysis capabilities that detect sensitive information in source code. Evidence: Static analysis phase of penetration test runs analyzes source code for sensitive information.
CWE-548: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
Partial

Description: The service may detect directory listing indirectly through path traversal testing but does not explicitly test for directory listing behavior. Evidence: Information disclosure and path traversal action groups test for file access. Limitations: Explicit validation of directory listing behavior is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-552: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties
Covered

Description: The service tests for files or directories accessible to external parties through path traversal and information disclosure testing. Evidence: Path traversal and information disclosure action groups test for accessible files and directories.
CWE-566: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key
Covered

Description: The service detects authorization bypass through user-controlled SQL primary keys via SQL injection findings. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate authorization bypass through SQL injection vulnerabilities.
CWE-59: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')
Partial

Description: The service may detect link following issues indirectly through path traversal testing but does not explicitly test for symbolic link following. Evidence: Path traversal action groups test for file access vulnerabilities. Limitations: Explicit validation of symbolic link following is not systematically performed and may be limited by testing environment constraints [UL-008].
CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
Partial

Description: The service does not include dedicated open redirect testing action groups. Evidence: Business logic testing may indirectly detect redirect issues but no explicit open redirect testing was observed. Limitations: Explicit redirect validation and open redirect attack testing is not performed [UL-008].
CWE-61: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following
Partial

Description: The service may detect symlink following issues indirectly through path traversal testing but does not explicitly test for UNIX symlink following. Evidence: Path traversal action groups test for file access vulnerabilities. Limitations: Explicit validation of symlink following is not systematically performed and may be limited by testing environment constraints or application platform compatibility [UL-008].
CWE-615: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments
Partial

Description: The service includes static analysis through code scanner but explicit scanning for sensitive information in source code comments may not be systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner action groups scan code repositories focusing on important flows and framework analysis. Limitations: Code scanner focuses on flow analysis rather than comprehensive comment scanning [UL-008].
CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
Covered

Description: The service detects authorization bypass through user-controlled keys via IDOR findings. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate comprehensive IDOR testing including parameter manipulation, session forging, and cross-user data access validation.
CWE-65: Windows Hard Link
Not Tested

Description: This vulnerability is Windows-specific and requires operating system-level analysis of hard link creation and following. Evidence: The tested applications are Linux-based web applications, making this Windows-specific vulnerability not applicable. Limitations:
CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere
Covered

Description: The service detects exposure of resources to wrong sphere through IDOR and information disclosure findings. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of cross-user resource exposure vulnerabilities.
CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource
Covered

Description: The service detects incorrect permission assignment for critical resources through privilege escalation findings. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of functionality accessible without proper authorization checks.
CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
Covered

Description: The service detects exposed dangerous methods or functions through findings that identify exposed endpoints with dangerous functionality. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of exposed endpoints with command execution and other dangerous functionality.
CWE-862: Missing Authorization
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects missing authorization through findings that identify functionality accessible without proper authorization checks. Evidence: Penetration test findings explicitly identify missing authorization where functionality should be restricted to specific roles.
CWE-863: Incorrect Authorization
Covered

Description: The service detects incorrect authorization through findings that demonstrate authorization bypass and privilege escalation. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate authorization bypass including authentication bypass and privilege escalation vulnerabilities.
CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
Covered

Description: The service includes dedicated SSRF testing action groups that systematically test for server-side request forgery vulnerabilities. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate advanced SSRF testing including chaining with command injection and lateral movement testing.
CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information
Covered

Description: The service detects insecure storage of sensitive information through findings that identify plaintext storage of credentials and sensitive data. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate detection of insecure credential storage vulnerabilities.

rows: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
Covered

Description: The service includes TLS scanner capabilities that systematically test for cookie security attributes including HttpOnly flag validation. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate clear detection of cookies missing the HttpOnly flag through TLS scanner action groups.
CWE-11: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
Not Tested

CWE-1174: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Improper Model Validation
Not Tested

CWE-13: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Password in Configuration File
Not Tested

Description: This vulnerability is ASP.NET-specific and requires ASP.NET framework analysis. Evidence: The tested applications are not ASP.NET-based, making this vulnerability not applicable to the test scenarios. Limitations:
CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting
Partial

Description: The service may detect configuration issues through code scanner and network scanner, but does not explicitly test for external control of system or configuration settings. Evidence: Configuration testing occurs through general scanning approaches rather than specific validation of configuration parameter sources and validation mechanisms. Limitations: Explicit testing for external control of system or configuration settings requires understanding configuration parameter sources and validation mechanisms which may not be systematically tested [UL-008].
CWE-16: Configuration
Covered

Description: The service tests for general configuration misconfigurations through code scanner, network scanner, and TLS scanner action groups. Evidence: Multi-layered scanning approach provides comprehensive configuration security testing across framework analysis, network configuration, and TLS/SSL settings.
CWE-260: Password in Configuration File
Partial

Description: The service includes static analysis capabilities through code scanner, but explicit scanning for passwords in configuration files may not be systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner focuses on important flows and framework analysis rather than comprehensive configuration file security scanning. Limitations: Configuration file password detection requires specific pattern matching for credentials that may not be comprehensively implemented in the code scanner [UL-008].
CWE-315: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie
Covered

Description: The service detects cleartext storage of sensitive information in cookies through TLS scanner and security header validation. Evidence: TLS scanner action groups validate cookie attributes and content, identifying cookies without proper security attributes that may indicate cleartext storage vulnerabilities.
CWE-489: Active Debug Code
Partial

Description: The service includes static analysis capabilities through code scanner, but explicit scanning for active debug code may not be systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner focuses on flow analysis rather than comprehensive debug code detection through pattern matching for debug statements and development-only code. Limitations: Debug code detection requires specific pattern matching for debug statements, logging, and development-only code that may not be comprehensively implemented [UL-008].
CWE-5: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
Covered

Description: The service includes dedicated TLS/SSL scanning capabilities that systematically test for data transmission without encryption. Evidence: TLS scanner uses industry-standard tools to validate encryption configuration, demonstrating comprehensive testing for unencrypted data transmission vulnerabilities.
CWE-526: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in an Environment Variable
Partial

Description: The service may detect sensitive information through code scanner, but explicit testing for cleartext storage of sensitive information in environment variables is not systematically performed. Evidence: Environment variable analysis requires runtime environment analysis or specific configuration file scanning that may not be part of the standard code scanning scope. Limitations: Environment variables are typically accessed at runtime rather than in source code, making static analysis less effective and requiring runtime environment analysis which may be outside the scope of static code scanning [UL-006].
CWE-547: Use of Hard-coded, Security-relevant Constants
Partial

Covered

Evidence: Business logic vulnerabilities and error handling testing may identify error conditions detected without action but do not explicitly test for this pattern. Limitations: Explicit validation of error conditions without action is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-391: Unchecked Error Condition
Partial

Description: The service may detect unchecked error conditions indirectly through error handling testing, but explicit validation of unchecked error condition patterns is not systematically performed. Evidence: Error handling testing may identify unchecked error conditions but does not explicitly test for unchecked error conditions as a specific vulnerability pattern. Limitations: Explicit validation of unchecked error condition patterns is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-394: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
Partial

Description: The service may detect unexpected status codes through network scanning and HTTP testing, but explicit validation of unexpected status code handling is not systematically performed. Evidence: Network scanner and HTTP testing may identify unexpected status codes but do not explicitly test for improper handling of unexpected status codes from external dependencies. Limitations: Explicit validation of unexpected status code handling is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-396: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
Partial

Description: The service may detect generic exception catching through static code analysis, but explicit runtime validation of exception handling patterns is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities may identify generic exception catching through static analysis but do not show explicit runtime testing for exception handling patterns. Limitations: Explicit runtime validation of exception handling patterns is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-397: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include testing for generic exception throwing declarations in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of testing for generic exception throwing declarations. Limitations: Explicit testing for generic exception throwing declarations is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-460: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
Covered

Description: The service tests for improper cleanup on thrown exceptions through business logic vulnerability testing. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate testing for scenarios where exceptions during operations could leave the system in an inconsistent state.
CWE-476: NULL Pointer Dereference
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include testing for NULL pointer dereference vulnerabilities in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of testing for NULL pointer dereference vulnerabilities. Limitations: Explicit testing for NULL pointer dereference vulnerabilities is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-478: Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include testing for missing default cases in multiple condition expressions in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of testing for missing default cases in switch statements or condition expressions. Limitations: Explicit testing for missing default cases is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-484: Omitted Break Statement in Switch
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include testing for omitted break statements in switch statements in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of testing for omitted break statements in switch statements. Limitations: Explicit testing for omitted break statements is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-550: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
Covered

Description: The service detects server-generated error messages containing sensitive information through SQL injection testing, error handling validation, and dedicated HTTP 500 error testing. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate identification of when applications expose detailed server-side exception information to users, including stack traces in HTTP 500 responses.
CWE-636: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
Partial

Description: The service may detect fail-open scenarios indirectly through authentication and authorization testing, but explicit validation of fail-open vs fail-closed behavior is not systematically performed. Evidence: Authentication and authorization testing may identify fail-open scenarios but do not explicitly test for fail-open behavior as a specific exceptional condition handling pattern. Limitations: Explicit validation of fail-open vs fail-closed behavior is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-703: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions
Covered

Description: The service detects improper exception handling through business logic testing, error response analysis, and dedicated HTTP 500 error testing. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate identification of when applications fail to properly check or handle exceptional conditions, as shown by unhandled exceptions resulting in HTTP 500 responses.
CWE-754: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions
Covered

Description: The service tests for improper checks of unusual or exceptional conditions through business logic vulnerability testing. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability testing demonstrates the tool's capability to identify when applications fail to check for concurrent access conditions and other unusual conditions.
CWE-755: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions
Covered

Description: The service detects improper handling of exceptional conditions through error response analysis, dedicated HTTP 500 error testing, and business logic testing. Evidence: Penetration test findings demonstrate identification of when applications fail to properly handle exceptions, as shown by HTTP 500 responses with detailed error information.
CWE-756: Missing Custom Error Page
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include testing for missing custom error pages in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of testing for missing custom error pages. Limitations: Explicit testing for missing custom error pages is not systematically performed [UL-007].

sections.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent represents a shift toward continuous, embedded application security. It automates design and code reviews, runs realistic multi-step penetration tests and centralizes findings, enabling teams to identify issues earlier and reduce manual effort. The service's context-aware approach, custom security requirements and multi-step attack simulations are valuable features.

However, the preview version has notable limitations: it is available only in one region, requires manual configuration through a web interface, supports only private GitHub repositories, lacks scheduling and API automation (scheduled testing is explicitly documented as unavailable [9]), and cannot handle complex exploitation scenarios or non-HTTP protocols. Only GitHub integration is supported; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available [3]. The service provides strong coverage for injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage for security misconfiguration and insecure design, but has significant gaps in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, logging and alerting, and data integrity failures. To fully secure their applications, organizations should use AWS Security Agent as a complementary control alongside additional tools and processes (e.g., dependency scanning, secrets management, infrastructureâasâcode security, and runtime monitoring) and maintain human expertise for nuanced assessments.

references.title: What is AWS Security Agent? - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing key capabilities (design security review, code security review, penetration testing), benefits (on-demand accessibility, automatic validation of organizational requirements, scalable security expertise, actionable fixes, multi and hybrid cloud support), and how the service operates across the development lifecycle. The documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi-step penetration testing within a centralized web interface.

references.title: AWS Security Agent (Preview): AI agent for proactive app security
references.description: AWS What's New announcement from December 2, 2025, announcing the preview of AWS Security Agent, an AI-powered agent that proactively secures applications throughout the development lifecycle. The announcement describes automated security reviews, context-aware penetration testing, and validation from design to deployment.

references.title: Review code security findings in GitHub - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation explaining how code review works in GitHub, including that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" and that draft pull requests are not analyzed

references.title: New AWS Security Agent secures applications proactively from design to deployment (preview)
references.description: AWS News Feed post summarising features including automated design, code and penetration tests, context awareness and OWASP Top 10 code checks

references.title: Service Quotas - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation listing service quotas including operations quotas (pentest hours: 80/month, design reviews: 200/month, code reviews: 1,000/month) and configuration quotas (integrations: 20 per account per region, integrated resources per integration: 20, custom security requirements: 20 per account per region, concurrent pentest runs: 5 per account per region)

references.title: Create a penetration test - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing how to create penetration tests, including prerequisites, configuration of test scope, target domains (only verified domains can be tested), VPC resources (only required for private applications), authentication credentials, and additional resources

references.title: AWS Debuts Security Agent for Automated Code-Level Protection
references.description: National CIO Review article noting that AWS Security Agent automates penetration testing tailored to application design and code

references.title: AWS targets vulnerable code with security agent
references.description: ComputerWeekly report highlighting that AWS Security Agent continuously scans for security violations, conducts on-demand penetration tests and ties security across the development lifecycle

references.title: Security Considerations for AWS Security Agent and AI assisted penetration testing - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security considerations, explicitly stating that AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule penetration test runs

references.title: Security best practices for AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security best practices, including code repository access limitations stating that AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories

references.title: Connect agent to private VPC resources - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on connecting the agent to private VPC resources, explicitly stating that VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported for VPC penetration tests

references.title: Infrastructure security in AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on infrastructure security, stating that AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations
